Improve this question                    I have to put a byte[] into a string , then convert it back to a byte] . However when I'm doing so , the returning byte[] is different from the original one .This is the code :public class HelloWorld {              public static void main(String[] args) {            byte[] data = {            (byte) 0xde, (byte) 0x33, (byte) 0x10, (byte) 0x12,            (byte) 0xde, (byte) 0x33, (byte) 0x10, (byte) 0x12,        };    System.out.println("OriginalDataByte : " + data);    String datastring = data.toString();    System.out.println("StringFromByteArray : " + datastring);    byte[] newdata = datastring.getBytes();    System.out.println("ByteArrayFromString: " + newdata);                          }}Returning :OriginalDataByte : [B@6d06d69cStringFromByteArray : [B@6d06d69cByteArrayFromString: [B@7852e922Any way to fix this ?
Please using this api: String.getBytes.

Improve this question                    I have to put a byte[] into a string , then convert it back to a byte] . However when I'm doing so , the returning byte[] is different from the original one .This is the code :public class HelloWorld {              public static void main(String[] args) {            byte[] data = {            (byte) 0xde, (byte) 0x33, (byte) 0x10, (byte) 0x12,            (byte) 0xde, (byte) 0x33, (byte) 0x10, (byte) 0x12,        };    System.out.println("OriginalDataByte : " + data);    String datastring = data.toString();    System.out.println("StringFromByteArray : " + datastring);    byte[] newdata = datastring.getBytes();    System.out.println("ByteArrayFromString: " + newdata);                          }}Returning :OriginalDataByte : [B@6d06d69cStringFromByteArray : [B@6d06d69cByteArrayFromString: [B@7852e922Any way to fix this ?
Please using this api: String.getBytes.
Answer: The problem you're encountering is due to the fact that the `toString()` method of a byte array returns the class name and the hash code of the array, not the actual content of the array. To convert a byte array to a string, you should use the `DatatypeConverter` class from the `javax.xml.bind.DatatypeConverter` package. Here's how you can modify your code:

```java
import javax.xml.bind.DatatypeConverter;

public class HelloWorld {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        byte[] data = {
            (byte) 0xde, (byte) 0x33, (byte) 0x10, (byte) 0x12,
            (byte) 0xde, (byte) 0x33, (byte) 0x10, (byte) 0x12,
        };
        System.out.println("OriginalDataByte : " + data);
        String datastring = DatatypeConverter.printBase64Binary(data);
        System.out.println("StringFromByteArray : " + datastring);
        byte[] newdata = DatatypeConverter.parseBase64Binary(datastring);
        System.out.println("ByteArrayFromString: " + newdata);
    }
}
```

This code will print the original byte array, convert it to a base64 string, and then convert it back to a byte array. The `printBase64Binary` method is used to convert a byte array to a base64 string, and the `parseBase64Binary` method is used to convert a base64 string back to a byte array.

Please note that the `DatatypeConverter` class is part of the Java API, so you don't need to import it separately.

Also, please note that the `printBase64Binary` method returns a string that is encoded in US-ASCII, which is a subset of UTF-8. If you need to use a different character encoding, you can specify it as the second argument to the `printBase64Binary` method.

This should solve your problem.

<<<api>>>: javax.xml.bind.DatatypeConverter
<<<code>>>: DatatypeConverter.printBase64Binary(data) and DatatypeConverter.parseBase64Binary(datastring)
<<<explanation>>>: These methods are used to convert a byte array to a base64 string and vice versa. The base64 string can be used to represent the byte array in a text format.
